Landing page

Project Introduction

Title: Analyzing Justice: Insights into Fairness and Disparity Regarding the Death Penalty

Motivation: This project explores the factors behind the death penalty in the United States, focusing on its fairness and implementation. With 23 states abolishing it, the death penalty remains a sensitive and controversial issue. By analyzing racial and geographical disparities, this research aims to provide an unbiased understanding of its patterns and impacts.

Research Questions

  1. What patterns emerge in the death penalty?
  2. Are there disparities in the death penalty?
  3. What predictive models can be developed to forecast whether or not someone will recieve the death penalty?
  4. How effective are current sentiments or policies?
  5. What actionable recommendations arise from the analysis?

Literature Review Highlights - Racial Disparity and the Death Penalty1

This case study examines the racial disparities in the administration of the death penalty, focusing on how the system treats Black offenders and victims compared to their White counterparts. The analysis contrasts two main arguments: the “mass market” claim, which suggests Black offenders are disproportionately sentenced to death, and the “specialist” argument, which highlights the undervaluation of Black victims in murder cases.

Key Findings

Victim Race Matters

  • Offenders who kill White victims are far more likely to receive the death penalty than those who kill Black victims.
  • This trend persists even when controlling for factors like the severity of the crime and aggravating circumstances.

Offender Race Shows Limited Impact

  • Studies show little evidence of racial bias against Black offenders in sentencing, once other factors are controlled.
  • In some cases, Black offenders are treated more leniently, particularly in non-capital cases.

Disparities Across Cases

  • Most murders are intraracial, with Black-on-Black and White-on-White homicides being the majority.
  • Black-on-White murders are punished more harshly than White-on-White murders, but White-on-Black murders receive harsher treatment than Black-on-Black cases, possibly due to societal or jury biases.

Implications

  • The greatest disparity is in the treatment of Black victims, whose lives are undervalued in the justice system.
  • Abolishing the death penalty may remove racial inequities in executions but would not address the broader systemic biases in how crimes are prosecuted and punished.

Conclusion

The racial disparities in the death penalty reflect deeper issues in the criminal justice system, particularly the undervaluation of Black victims. While reform is necessary, simply abolishing the death penalty does not guarantee fairness, as inequities would persist in other forms of punishment. The study calls for systemic reforms to address these broader biases.

Literature Review Highlights - Counties and the Death Penalty2

Key Findings

Counties with a history of imposing death sentences are significantly more likely to continue doing so, regardless of current homicide rates, demonstrating a strong self-reinforcing effect.

Predictive power of prior use

The cumulative number of prior death sentences in a county is a stronger predictor of future death sentences than homicide rates, emphasizing the capricious nature of the system.

Geographical concentration

A disproportionate number of death sentences are concentrated in a few counties, driven more by local historical practices than by crime severity or frequency.

Racial dynamics

Counties with higher historical rates of racial violence, such as lynchings during the Jim Crow era, are more likely to exhibit high rates of death penalty use.

Implications

The system’s reliance on self-referential and racial dynamics undermines principles of equal protection, echoing the concerns of arbitrariness and racial bias raised by the Supreme Court in 1972.

Literature Review Highlights - Who Lives, Who Dies, Who Decides3

Persisting racial disparities

Studies reveal that racial bias in the death penalty has remained prevalent over time and across all regions of the United States.

Racial impact on sentencing odds

Black defendants face nearly four times higher odds of receiving a death sentence compared to others for similar crimes, even after controlling for case severity.

White dominance in decision-making

Nearly 98% of district attorneys in death penalty cases are white, contributing to the racial imbalance in sentencing.

Correlation with historical injustices

The racial biases in death penalty application reflect the legacy of slavery, lynchings, and Jim Crow laws.

Disparities in victim focus

Death penalty cases disproportionately favor white victims over Black victims, reinforcing racial inequities in justice.

Systematic failures to address bias

Despite overwhelming evidence, courts and legislatures have largely ignored racial disparities in death penalty cases, exacerbating systemic injustice.

Audience and Relevance

This project is designed for data professionals, researchers, policymakers, and the general public. Through this analysis, I aim to influence public opinion and inform political discourse on the death penalty. By presenting data-driven insights, I hope to foster meaningful conversations that challenge biases and contribute to policy changes that promote fairness and justice.

Call to Action

Explore my project findings and methodology on this site, or connect with me to discuss collaboration opportunities and strategies for influencing public opinion and shaping policies on the death penalty.

References

1.
McAdams, J. C. Racial disparity and the death penalty. Law and Contemporary Problems 61, 153–170 (1998).
2.
Baumgartner, F. R., Box-Steffensmeier, J. M., Campbell, B. W., Caron, C. & Sherman, H. Learning to kill: Why a small handful of counties generates the bulk of US death sentences. PLoS One 15, e0240401 (2020).
3.
Center, D. P. I. The death penalty in black and white: Who lives, who dies, who decides. (2024).
